nodes.label: GOYA
nodes.author of: Piedad (1774), Aníbal vencedor (1771), tapestry cartoons (1775-1792), prints after Velázquez (1778), Crucifixion (1780), San Bernardino de Siena (1781-83), The Duchess of Osuna (1785), The Dukes of Osuna (1787-88), Yard of lunatics (1794), Witches Flight (1797-98), Album A (c.1794-95), Album B (c.1795-97), Caprichos (1799), Allegory of Truth, Time and History (1800), The Family of Charles IV (1800), Clothed Maja (1802-05), Bandit stripping a woman (1808-12), The Burial of the Sardine (1808-12), Portrait of Antonia de Zárate (1810-11), Disasters of War (1810-15), The Second of May 1808 (1814), The Third of May 1808 (1814), Ferdinand VII (1814-15), Self-Portrait (1815), Tauromaquia (1816), Disparates (c.1816-19), Black Paintings (c.1819-23), Bulls of Bordeaux (1825), Portrait of Mariano Goya (1827)

nodes.students: Felipe Arrojo; Asensio Julià; Rosario Weiss
nodes.portrayed by: Vicente López (1826, Prado); Francisco de Goya y Lucientes
nodes.curiosities: he became completely deaf after a serious illness in 1792-93

nodes.label: Federico Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: 1833 (1st trip; with Vicente Masarnau): he meets Baron Taylor and Adrien Dauzats; 1837-1839 (portrays Adrien Dauzats 1837): he benefits from contacts with Baron Taylor; 1838 commission from Louis-Philippe for painting 'Godofredo de Bouillon' for Versailles
nodes.address: 1833 Paris: Hôtel Bourbonne-Les-Bains (very close to Adrien Dauzat's)
nodes.author of: illustrations in El Artista; Godofredo de Bouillon proclamado rey de Jerusalén (1838, Galerie Batailles, Palais Versailles); Isabel II de España (1850); Doña Amalia de Llano y Dotres, Condesa de Vilches (1853); Carolina Coronado (c.1855); Eduardo Rosales (1867); El pintor Perugino Sensi (1873, Prado)
nodes.portrayed by: Raimundo Madrazo, 1875, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao
nodes.works as: Director of RABASF in 1866; Pintor de Cámara of Isabel II; Director of the Prado Museum 1860-68 and 1881-1894; Senator
nodes.masters: Alberto Lista; Franz Xaver Winterhalter; Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres
nodes.students: León Abadías y Santolaria; Ricardo Villodas y de la Torre
nodes.parents: José Madrazo and Isabel Kuntz y Valentini

nodes.label: Carderera
mentions of Goya: 1835 El Artista 2, 'Biografía de D. Francisco Goya, pintor', 253-55: 'La nueva escuela romántica de los pintores franceses ha puesto en evidencia el mérito de nuestro artista, y en bastantes cuadros pequeños y en muchísimas litografías y aguas fuertes que adornan las ediciones de Victor Hugo y otros célebres contemporáneos, se ve el deseo de imitar a Goya, y se columbran los originales y románticos duendecitos esparcidos en sus ochenta caprichos' (p.255) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.325). With a lithography by Federico Madrazo (Vicente López's portrait of Goya).

1838-VII-15 Semanario Pintoresco español 120, 631-33: 'Los aficionados estrangeros tiempo ha las buscan [Los Caprichos] con mas pasion que los nuestros, y hoy vemos reproducidos y transformados sus duendecitos y alguaciles en los grabados y litografiados que nos vienen de allende sin pretensión de ocultar el plagio' (p.633) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.328)

1860-VIII-15 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 7, 'François Goya: sa vie, ses dessins et ses eaux-fortes', 215-27, translated and annotated by Philippe Burty, with a preface by Charles Blanc and a print by Bracquemond. It includes a short biography of Goya and an account of his drawings. Carderera claims ownership of 2 sheets from Album A, 112 preparatory drawings of the Caprichos, 50 of Tauromaquia and 72 of Disasters of War (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.347).

1863-VII-1 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 15, 'François Goya', 237-49. It focuses on the advertisement of the Caprichos in the Diario de Madrid (6 Feb 1799). It includes Jacquemart's 'Spanish scene', based on Goya. Also mentions the Prado commentaries. It quotes Théophile Gautier's essay on the Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, 1845, p.136). He mixes up the Disparates with the drawing series Sueños ('Les proverbes ou rêves', p.244) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.350).
nodes.image source: portrait by Federico Madrazo, Museo de Huesca 00046

nodes.label: José Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: in 1829 (1st trip): sees Eugène Delacroix's work
nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara of Carlos IV; reorganises and catalogues the collections of the Prado Museum; 1823 teacher of painting at the RABASF and Deputy Director
nodes.editor of: a catalogue of the Prado collection with lithographic illustrations of the paintings (made by Pharamond Blanchard)
nodes.collector of: a valuable painting collection, partly acquired by José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)
nodes.students: Léon Bonnat; José María Avrial y Flores; Pedro Kuntz y Valentini
nodes.author of: La muerte de Viriato (1807, Prado)
nodes.children: Federico Madrazo, Pedro Madrazo, Luis Madrazo, Juan Madrazo, Carlota Madrazo

nodes.label: Baron Taylor
nodes.profession: politician, artist, playwright, philanthropist, military member
nodes.in Spain: 1st trip in 1820; 1823 [Cien Mil hijos de S. Luis]; in 1832 (with Dauzats); July 1833 (with Dauzats): introduced to José Madrazo by Blanchard, portrayed by Madrazo; 1835-36 commissioned by Louis-Philippe to acquire paintings for Galerie espagnole (assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and benefited by active help and advice of Madrazo family and Carderera [Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p.574]): 1836 Feb-Aug paintings (8 Goyas from Javier Goya)
nodes.worked for: Charles X; Louis-Philippe: acquiring Spanish paintings for the Galerie espagnole (1838-48)
works as: Administrateur général de la Comédie-Française (1825-30, 1831-38): he stages Alexandre Dumas's 'Henri III et sa cour', and Hugo's 'Hernani' and 'Marion Delorme'.

Commissaire du roi (Charles X) auprès du Pacha d'Égypte (1830): commissioned with gathering Egyptian antiquities for the Louvre (with a credit of 100.000 fr.). He brings the Luxor obelisk to Paris (Place de la Concorde since 1836).
Inspecteur général des Beaux-Arts (1835): Galerie espagnole.
nodes.author of: Voyage pittoresque en Espagne, en Portugal et sur la côte d’Afrique, de Tanger a Tétuan (1826); 'Voyages pittoresques et romantiques dans l'ancienne France', in collaboration with Charles Nodier and Alphonse de Cailleux (started in 1818; published 1820-1878)
nodes.member of: Académie Française, Académie des beaux-arts (1847); Société des gens de lettres; Fondation Taylor
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo, oil painting (1833); Nadar, photograph (1877)
nodes.participates in: l'Expédition d'Espagne (1823), also known as los Cien Mil Hijos de San Luis: campaign to restore the Bourbon dinasty in Spain
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier (1822), Officier (1834), Commandeur (1837) et Grand officer (1877) de la Légion d'Honneur
nodes.parents: Hélie Taylor (English born) and Marie-Jacqueline Walwein (Belgian)
nodes.curiosities: There is a Fondation Taylor, still running, created in 1844

nodes.label: Dauzats
nodes.in Spain: in 1832 (with Baron Taylor); July 1833 (with Baron Taylor); 1835-1837 assists Baron Taylor in acquisition of artworks for Galerie espagnole (alongside Pharamond Blanchard)
nodes.author of: 1834 article in Magasin pittoresque? (mentions Prado commentaries, in the possession of Javier Goya until 1861)

nodes.label: Blanchard
nodes.in Spain: 1824-1837 working as a painter and engraver; hired by José Madrazo to make lithographic reproductions at the Real Museo in Madrid; 1835-37 he assists Baron Taylor in acquiring paintings for Louis Philippe's Galerie espagnole
nodes.in Paris: after 1837 (quoted by Carderera's diary) (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.537)
nodes.author of: 'Course de taureaux dans un bourg d'Espagne' (Salon 1834)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Eugenio Ochoa
nodes.in Paris: 1828-1834 at the École d'Arts et d'Offices. He meets Moratín and Godoy; 1837-1845
author of: Translation of Victor Hugo's Hernani (watched by Théophile Gautier in 1840 in Valladolid)

1844 'Catálogo razonado de los manuscritos españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París: seguido de un suplemento que contiene los de las otras tres bibliotecas públicas' (Arsenal, Ste Geneviève and Mazarine), París, Imprenta Real

1861 'Paris, Londres y Madrid': he mentions Dumas, Balzac, Gautier, Delacroix, Dauzats, Nodier, Lamartine, Ingres, Vernet, Decamps, Delaroche, Eugène Sue, Feuillet, Houssaye and others. He does not mention Goya, Taylor, Javier Goya or Mariano Goya. HathiTrust [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044014808356&seq=203&q1=Sand]
nodes.editor of: El Artista (1835) con Federico Madrazo: spreads Romanticism in Spain and imitates the French journal L'Artiste

nodes.label: Mérimée
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: in 1830 (doesn't mention Goya in his account)

nodes.label: Iriarte
nodes.works for: Fernando VI, Carlos III, Carlos IV, José I
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1797, Strasbourg Museum of Fine Arts

nodes.label: Ferdinand Guillemardet
nodes.profession: diplomat (French ambassador 1798-1800), medical doctor, politician (representative of the Convention)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: a set of the Caprichos; his portrait (1798, Louvre MI697); Portrait of Mariana Waldstein, 9th Marquise of Santa Cruz (c.1797-99, Louvre RF1976-79) [authorship doubts]
nodes.commissions Goya with: portrait, 1798, Louvre MI697 (GW.677). This was the first work by Goya to enter the Louvre (donated by his heirs in 1865)

nodes.label: Delacroix
nodes.author of: Scenes from the Massacre at Chios (1824, Louvre), The Death of Sardanapalus (1827, Louvre), Liberty guiding the People (1830, Louvre)
nodes.knows Goya's works: by c.1819, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (Lipschutz 1972, p.10)

nodes.label: Llorente
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'afrancesados'
nodes.collector of Goya's works: his portrait (1810-11); a set of the Caprichos (probably bought c.1810 when sitting for his portrait).
nodes.disseminates Goya's works: he brings his Caprichos set to France in 1813 during his exile, and wrote an interpretation of them in French (Boston MFA 1973.730), probably to be shared among French speakers (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.35). Since Goya himself was alive in 1813 and in possession of his original explanations of the Caprichos (known as the Prado commentaries), Llorente probably knew this text directly through him, perhaps during his portrait sittings (c.1810)
nodes.works as: Comisario General de Cruzada (1810-11); Comisario del Santo Oficio; Secretario supernumerario de la Inquisición de Corte; canon of Calahorra (1790); literary censor for the Consejo de Castilla; member of the Junta Nacional for Joseph Bonaparte, Consejero de Estado para Asuntos Eclesiásticos, and Caballero comendador de la Orden Real de España (1809)
nodes.in France: exiled from July 1813, first at Lectoure, then Bordeaux, then Paris (1814). In Paris, he publishes 'Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole' (1817-18) in 4 volumes.
nodes.in Spain: back in 1820, after being expelled from France (during the Bourbon restoration) for being a liberal and a Carbonari
nodes.political views: liberal. Supporter of Regalism. Member of Carbonari (secret revolutionary society, patriotic and liberal in nature). Works for the reform of the clergy in Spain
nodes.studies in: Universidad de Zaragoza. Doctor in Canonical Law
nodes.author of: a report about the Inquisition (1793); Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole (1817-18) in 4 volumes; Retrato político de los Papas (1823); Historia crítica de la inquisición de España (1835).
nodes.member of: Real Sociedad Económica de La Rioja (1805)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1810-11, Museo de Arte de São Paulo
nodes.curiosities: he wrote a zarzuela, El recluta gallego (1782)

nodes.label: Brugada
nodes.curiosities: he sees Goya die in Bordeaux, alongside Molina (Canellas, Diplomatario,  no.181, p.512)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Ceán Bermúdez
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: manager of the Archivo de Indias; Secretary's officer for the Estado de Gracia y Justicia de Indias
nodes.author of: Colección lithographica de cuadros del Rey de España el Sr. D. Fernando VII (1826-37); Diccionario histórico de los más ilustres profesores de las Bellas Artes en España (1800); Sumario de las antigüedades romanas que hay en España, en especial las pertenecientes a las Bellas Artes (1832, postumous)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1785 (private collection)
nodes.collector of: Dürer, José de Ribera, Piranesi, among others
nodes.married to: Manuela Camas y de las Heras

nodes.label: Moratín
nodes.mentions of Goya: Diary, 21 May 1798 (Canellas no.88): they see together the paintings of San Antonio de la Florida?

nodes.label: Gaulon
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1824-25, lithography (Harris 1964, no.282)

nodes.label: Matheron
nodes.writes about Goya: first biography of Goya, 'Goya', 1858, París, Schulz et Thuillié (digitised in Prado Biblioteca https://www.museodelprado.es/aprende/biblioteca/biblioteca-digital/fondo/goya/47f25eaf-29e1-dd74-6727-6227f053e2a2)

nodes.label: Aguado
nodes.Full name: Alejandro María Aguado y Remírez de Estenoz
nodes.profession: banker, military member, collector, patron of arts
nodes.collection: formed from two collections: that of Bernardo de Iriarte and the Count of Altamira (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV). Around 360 paintings, mainly by Spanish artists, including Velázquez, Murillo, Ribera and Zurbarán, as well as Italians like Leonardo da Vinci, Rafael, and Dutch-Flemish like Rubens and Rembrandt
nodes.patronage: acquired the Théâtre-Italien (or Comédie-italienne), funded the journals Revue de Paris and Le Constitutionnel, acted as the President of the Athénée des arts
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Lacoma y Fontanet, 1832 (Madrid, Museo del Romanticismo, CE0509); unknown artist (Palais de Versailles, MV 6727)
nodes.aristocratic titles: I marqués de las Marismas del Guadalquivir

nodes.label: Devéria
nodes.works as: director of the Département des Estampes at the BNF in 1849
nodes.address: 45 rue de Nôtre Dame des Champs (1833)

nodes.label: Fontaney
nodes.in Spain: 1830-1831, accompanying the Duke d'Harcourt (Eugène d'Harcourt), ambassador of France in Spain
nodes.author of: Ballades, mélodies et poésies diverse (1829); Scènes de la vie castillane et andalouse (article series in Revue des Deux Mondes)
nodes.shows Goya: Fontaney's journal (8 Sept 1831): 'Evening at l'Arsenal; Mélanie, Louise [Soulié] were there. I showed them the Goya' (ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31); 9 Nov 1831, at Belloc's: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc [Louise Swanton-Belloc], Mlle de Montgolfier [Adélaïde de Montgolfier]. (...) (Auguste) Blanqui the conspirator with a long white beard, (Jean-Alexandre) Plocque; (Auguste) Barthélémy;--a fat man who states in regard to Goya: It is not lacking in verve' (p.71)
nodes.partners/lovers: Gabrielle Dorval (daughter of the actress Marie Dorval). They flee together to Spain and England (where he falls sick with phthisis)
nodes.pseudonyms: Lord Feeling (from the Scottish writer Henry Mackenzie)
nodes.curiosities: after dying of phthisis, both Hugo and Sainte-Beuve forget their recent fallout and attend his funeral

nodes.label: Hugo
nodes.profession: author, essayist, novelist, playwright, poet, politician
nodes.author of: Cromwell (play) (1827); Les Orientales (poetry) (1829): illustrated by Louis Boulanger; Le Dernier jour d'un condamné (1829); Hernani (play) (1830): takes place in Spain; Marion Delorme (play) (1831); Les Feuilles d'automne (poetry) (1831); Notre-Dame de Paris (novel) (1831); Le roi s'amuse (play) (1832: forbidden); Ruy Blas (play) (1838); Les Misérables (novel) (1862); Torquemada (poetry) (1869).
nodes.works as: Peer of France (1845-48); Member of the National Assembly for Seine (1848-51); Member of the National Assembly for Gironde (1871); Senator for Seine (1876-1882)
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members George Sand, Alexandre Dumas and Honoré de Balzac. Académie française (1841-1885)
nodes.political views: as a Pair de France in the Upper Chamber of Parliament (1845), he spoke against the death penalty and social injustice, and in favour of freedom of the press and self-government for Poland. With Napoleon III's seize of power in 1851, he declared him a traitor to France and moved to Brussels, then Jersey, then the Channel Islands, where he was in exile 1855-1870. However, he justified colonialism in terms of a civilising mission, although he was an abolitionist of slavery. During the Paris Commune, he was very critical of both sides. He was also famously anticlerical.
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Alaux (1825; Maison Victor Hugo 253); Achille Devéria, lithograph (1829); Charles Hugo, photograph (c.1853-55); Étienne Carjat, photograph, 1875
nodes.studies in: Real Colegio de San Antonio de Abad (Madrid); Lycée Louis le Grand (Paris)
nodes.children: Léopold Hugo, Léopoldine Hugo, Charles Hugo, François-Victor Hugo, Adèle Hugo
nodes.parents: Joseph Léopold Hugo and Sophie Trébuchet
nodes.curiosities: on 10 July 1816, he wrote in his diary: 'I shall be Chateaubriand or nothing'. He frequented spiritism during his exile, and participated in séances conducted by Madame Delphine de Girardin. When asked in 1872 if he was a Catholic, he answered, 'No. A Freethinker'. Notre-Dame de Paris was listed as a 'forbidden book' by the Church.

nodes.label: Gautier
nodes.author of: 1840 Spanish trip essays in La Presse, reedited as Tra los montes (1843) and as Voyage en Espagne (1845). 1843 August: Gautier, ‘La Tauromachie’, Le Musée des familles, pp. 341–48.13 Illustrated with seven drawings by Gautier (signed ‘T. G.’) engraved by ‘A.B.L’ (Andrew, Best and Leloir) (see Fayos Pérez 2024); Histoire du romantisme (1874).
mentions of Goya: 1832-VIII-5, Onophrius Wphly, La France littéraire, pp.388-418: 'El sueno de la razon produce monstruos. Goya' (Capricho 43)
1838-VII-5, Les Caprices de Goya; (La Presse): mentions Goya's Album B of drawings?
1842 ‘Franco Goya y Lucientes’, Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 337–45 (with Valentín Carderera's help [Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.550]).
1845 mentions Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, nouvelle édition révue, p.136) [quoted by Valentín Carderera in 1863] (Fayos Pérez 2024).

1855 Les Beaux-arts en Europe: 'L'Espagne a oublié Velasquez, Ribera, Murillo, Zurbaran et même Goya; elle ne peint plus avec sa sombre palette d'autrefois des moines au froc brun [...] elle n'a plus cette ardeur farouche, cette passion catholique qui la caractérisaient [...]' (p.8)

1874 Histoire du romantisme: 'Victor Hugo, s’il n’était pas poète, serait un peintre de premier ordre ; il excelle à mêler, dans des fantaisies sombres et farouches, les effets de clair-obscur de Goya à la terreur architecturale de Piranèse'; '[...] cette entente des terreurs nocturnes qu’on ne rencontre que dans les Caprices de Goya'; '[Louis Boulanger] Tantôt c’était Rubens, tantôt c’était Véronèse, et puis Titien ; d’autres fois, franchissant les monts, il allait à Velasquez et à Goya'.
nodes.in Spain: in 1840 (with Piot), watches Hugo's Hernani (translated by Eugenio Ochoa; Gautier praises the translation)
nodes.knows Goya's works: Los Caprichos: in late 1830-late 1831 (Lipschutz 1972, p.118); through Antoine Fontaney? (brought Caprichos set in January 1831); Goya's drawings by 1838 (see Fayos Pérez 2024)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Bulls of Bordeaux; Tauromaquia (lot 66, 24-25 Feb 1873 sale): sold Sotheby's Paris, 14 Dec 2022, lot 37 (showing Valentín Carderera's dedicatory to Gautier); Tauromaquia set given by Valentín Carderera on 13 Nov 1859 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.431)

nodes.label: Balzac
nodes.author of: La Comédie humaine (1831-50), including La peau du chagrin (1831), which mentions Murillo and Velázquez;  Le Chef-d'œuvre inconnu (1831); Les Cent Contes drolatiques (1832-37); Eugénie Grandet (1834); Le Père Goriot (1835).
nodes.participates in: 'Les français peints par eux-mêmes' (1840) (ed. Léon Curmer), alongside Théophile Gautier, Alexandre Dumas, J. J. Grandville, Honoré Daumier and Paul Gavarni; J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Charles Nodier and George Sand.
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas and George Sand
nodes.works as: President of the Société des gens de lettres (1839-1840)
nodes.masters: François Guizot; Abel-François Villemain; Victor Cousin
nodes.political views: ambiguous. A legitimist during the July Revolution (1830). He declares himself a liberal. Defends the working class. While expressing some conservative ideas, his work was admired by Marx and Engels, and reflects some elements close to Anarchism.
nodes.writes in: Revue des Deux Mondes, La Presse, Le Constitutionnel, Le Siècle
nodes.studies in: Lycée Charlemagne (1814-18); Sorbonne Université (from 1816); Faculté de Droit (1816-19)
nodes.pseudonyms: Horace de Saint-Aubin, Lord R’Hoone, Viellerglé, Saint Aubin
nodes.portrayed by: Louis-Auguste Bisson, 1842, daguerrotype
nodes.partners/lovers: Henirette de Maillé de La Tour-Landry; Laure de Berny (1823-1833); Olympe Pélissier; Maria du Fresnay (desde 1833); Caroline Marbouty (1833-1839)

nodes.label: Dumas
nodes.author of: Les Trois Mousquetaires (1844); Le Comte de Monte-Cristo (1844-46); La Reine Margot (1845)
mentions of Goya: 1837-V-28 28 ‘[…] Goya, ce fantaisiaque [sic] élève de Tiepolo le Vénitien, avec lequel est mort la grande peinture espagnole, et qui dans ses compositions, dont la vérité a fait des satires, a tout attaqué: moines, nobles et rois’ (p. 2). About the Galerie espagnole: ‘[…] doté la France d’un trésor qui allait être perdu pour le monde, et rapporté pour 800,000 francs, quatre cents tableaux qui valent trois millions’ (p. 2) ‘Feuilleton: M. le Baron Taylor en Espagne’, La Presse, 1–2 [digitised in Gallica]

1845-I-16 'C’était un spectacle à la fois lugubre et bizarre, que tous ces élégans [sic] seigneurs et toutes ces belles dames défilant comme une procession, peinte par Goya, au milieu de ces squelettes noircis et de ces gibets aux longs bras décharnés’ (‘Feuilleton: La Reine Margot, second volume’, La Presse, pp.1–3) [digitised in Gallica]

1849-V-3 ‘On dirait une de ces gravures de Goya, où, dans la demi-teinte, des arracheurs de dents font la chasse aux pendus’ (‘Feuilleton: Les mille et un fantomes’, Le Constitutionnel, p.1) [digitised in Gallica]

nodes.label: Nodier
nodes.writes in: La Quotidienne (1821-1830): he presents the work of Walter Scott, Rabelais, Marot, Lamartine, Byron and Victor Hugo; Revue des Deux Mondes; Revue de Paris (from 1829)
nodes.participates in: J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Honoré de Balzac and George Sand
nodes.political views: favourable to the French Revolution (Société des amis de la Constitution; Club des Jacobins), but also Royalist. Essentially against despotic power.
nodes.works as: librarian of the comte d'Artois, future Charles X. He lives at the Arsenal (Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal), where he holds a literary salon known as a 'cénacle' (mentioned by Dumas as a place where all the big names of Romantic literature were present). Dismissed by Polignac in July 1830, then reinstated by Louis-Philippe when the Library passed to the state in August.
nodes.portrayed by: Paulin Guérin; lithograph in Cénacle de la Muse française (1827)
nodes.author of: Smarra ou les Démons de la nuit (1821): of massive influence in the Romantic generation; Infernalia (1822); Trillby ou le lutin d'Argail (1822); Examen critique des dictionnaires de la langue française (1828); Le Vieux Marinier (1832).
nodes.editor of: 'Adèle, Mélanges de littérature et de critique' and 'Lord Ruthwen ou les Vampires' by Cyprien Bérard
nodes.founder of: the Bulletin du bibliophile, with the bookseller Techener (whose collection included a set of Goya's Caprichos in the 1841 sale)

nodes.masters: Justin Girod de Chantrans (botanique, entomologie, minéralogie); Euloge Schneider (Greek); Joseph Droz
nodes.curiosities: in 1797 he was member of a secret society called the Philadelphes. Later, he was a member of the 4th society of Caveau (1834-39) ('société bachique'), dedicated to drinking, singing and literature.

nodes.label: Hamelin
nodes.profession: socialite, salonnière, 'Merveilleuse' during the Directoire, real state agent, secret agent
nodes.political views: fervent Bonapartist (surveilled by Louis XVIII's Police). Enthusiastic about the Revolution of 1848
nodes.works as: secret agent for Napoléon Bonaparte. Elle 'fit placarder sur les murs de Paris des affiches portant le texte des trois proclamations adressées par l’Empereur à son armée et au peuple français' (Wikipedia).

nodes.bibliography: 5 years after her death, Salvandy wrote in Le Journal des débats (18 July 1856): 'Une étrangère, une Américaine (nom donné aux colons des Antilles), arriva sur la terre de France, jeune, belle, éprise de notre littérature, de nos arts, de notre société (...) Elle avait retenu autour d'elle les esprits les plus diverses, les éléments qu'on aurait pu croire étrangers entre eux, l'Empire et la Royauté, l'Institut et le grand monde (...) un des rares salons où se maintenait la conversation à travers tout le mouvement de la société d'aujourd'hui'.
nodes.curiosities: around rue Balzac, it was known as 'quartier de l'Avenue Fortunée' in her honour. The Comtesse de Bassanville said about her, 'C'est surtout par l'esprit que brillait Madame Hamelin ; elle n'était pas simplement spirituelle, elle était l'esprit même'. Mademoiselle Cochelet in her 'Mémoires' wrote 'Ce furent selon les bruits du temps, les complots de Madame Hamelin et de la reine (Hortense) qui amenèrent ce merveilleux débarquement de l'île d'Elbe'.
nodes.bibliography: Maurice Lescure, Madame Hamelin : Merveilleuse et turbulente fortunée, 1776-1851, 1995

nodes.label: Swanton-Belloc
nodes.author of: the translations of 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' (1852) by Harriet Beecher Stowe, the memoirs of Lord Byron, the works of Walter Scott, and four works by Charles Dickens, among others. She also authored over forty books, including a life of Byron, published with an introduction by Stendhal. She co-authored with Adélaïde de Montgolfier a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.participated in: a project after the 1830 Revolution to help General Lafayette establish public libraries in France, but it did not succeed (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)

nodes.curiosities: she was buried alongside her close friend Adélaïde de Montgolfier (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud. She was friends with Charles Dickens and Harriet Beecher Stowe. Her son would marry a prominent English feminist, Bessie Rayner Parkes, and they had two children who would become prolific writers: Marie Adelaide Belloc Lowndes (novelist) and Hilaire Belloc (poet and historian)

nodes.label: Jovellanos
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: liberal. He was a key agent in the so-called 'reformismo ilustrado', especially regarding economic and cultural development. However, with the French Revolution he paralised the liberal ideas and removed from office any liberal thinkers. With the fall of his friend Francisco Cabarrús, Jovellanos left the Court and went into exile in 1790. He returned to politics in 1797 as Ministro de Gracia y Justicia and tried to reform the Justice system and decrease the influence of the Inquisition, but he resigned after 9 months. He went back to Asturias in 1798 and worked on the study of the Asturian language. In 1800 Manuel Godoy orders his arrest and he is exiled in Mallorca, imprisoned at the Real Cartuja de Jesús de Nazaret, then at the Castle of Bellver. Liberated in 1808, he refused to take part in José Bonaparte's government. He represented Asturias in the Junta Central
nodes.works as: Ministro de Gracia y Justicia (1797-98); contributed to the creation of Banco de San Carlos (1782)
author of: Politics: Informe sobre la ley agraria (1784); Memoria sobre la educación pública; Memoria en defensa de la Junta Central; Representación al Rey sobre el tribunal de la Inquisición (1797), quoting Juan Antonio Llorente's report on the Inquisition

Diary and memoirs: facsimile (Biblioteca Digital Hispánica), transcribed in Obras completas, II, 1857, 4th ed. (Biblioteca de Autores Españoles; Cervantes Virtual); travel diary from Bellver to Guadalajara (April-June 1808)
nodes.founder of: Real Instituto Asturiano de Náutica y Mineralogía in Gijón (1794), applying Enlightenment ideas
nodes.member of: RABASF (1780), Real Academia de la Historia (1779), Real Academia Española (1781)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1798 (Prado P003255); attribution to Antonio Carnicero, c.1797 (Museo Lázaro Galdiano)
nodes.studies in: Real Monasterio de Santo Tomás (University of Ávila)
nodes.correspondence: Obras completas, ed. José Miguel Caso González, 1985, 1986, 1988, 1990

nodes.label: Floridablanca
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: he was a key agent in the so-called 'reformismo ilustrado', encouraging improvements in infraestructures, administration and economy (such as the creation of the Dirección General de Caminos, 1785). However, he opposed the ideas of the French Revolution and became more conservative; he implemented censorship and reinforced the Inquisition, controlling the border to avoid the spread of revolutionary ideas. External politics: he made Spain participate in the Independence War at the US against Great Britain, getting back the territories of Menorca and Florida. His rivals were Count of Aranda (more liberal and pro-Revolution) and Manuel Godoy (his successor)
nodes.works as: Primer Secretario de Estado (1777-92); Secretario de Gracia y Justicia (1782-90)
nodes.member of: Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Pompeo Batoni, c.1776 (Art Institute of Chicago); Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1783 (Prado P003255)
nodes.decorations/awards: Caballero de la Orden del Toisón de Oro; Orden de Carlos III
nodes.curiosities: Carlos III awards him with the title of Count of Floridablanca (1773) for his work as ambassador at the Holy See, contributing to the abolition of the Jesuit order

nodes.political views: liberal. Political feuds. Imprisoned in 1790 for an alleged fraud. Afterwards he returns to politics with Carlos IV. Afrancesado during the Napoleonic invasion (named caballero Gran Banda de la Orden Real de España by Joseph Bonaparte); he is arrested in June 1808 in Zaragoza alongside Jovellanos; he then works for Joseph Bonaparte until his death in 1810

nodes.member of: Sociedad económica de amigos del país

nodes.curiosities: he was buried in the Capilla de la Concepción at the Sevilla cathedral (during the Napoleonic War). After the war, his remains were exhumed and allegedly thrown in the common grave at the Patio de los Naranjos (with the victims of death penalty), or to the Guadalquivir river

edges.collaborations: in 1828, Delacroix designs the costumes for Hugo's 'Amy Robsart', a play based on Walter Scott's 'Kenilworth' (1821). It premieres on 13 Feb 1828 at Odeón and it was Hugo's first play to be staged, but it closes after only one night. Wikipedia https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Robsart_(pièce_de_théâtre)
edges.comparisons: on 4 Nov 1826 in Le Globe, the critic Dubois compares Hugo with Delacroix: 'M. Victor Hugo est en poèsie ce que M. Delacroix est en peinture : il y a toujours une grande idée, un sentiment profond sous ces traits incorrects et heurtés ; et je l'avoue, pour moi, j'aime cette vigueur jeune et âpre; j'en puis blâmer de sang-froid les oeuvres, mais ces oeuvres mêmes me font sortir de ce sang-froid mortel à l'art; et c'est bien là un mérite aujourd'hui' (p.186) (see Hovasse 2001, p.325, note 115)
edges.bibliography: Hovasse, Victor Hugo, t.I (1802-1851), 2001, p.325 (about Delacroix's work for 'Amy Robsart'; Hovasse: 'Le jugement de Hugo sur les femmes de Delacroix était connu, car Baudelaire y fait allusion dans son article sur l’exposition universelle de 1855 paru dans Le Pays' (Œuvres complètes, ed. Claude Pichois, Gallimard, Bibliothèque de la Pléiade, t.II, 1976, p.593); 'C’est un peu avant 1827, donc avant Les Orientales, que quelques critiques, comme Dubois dans Le Globe du 4 nov 1826, s’avisèrent de rapprocher l’art de Delacroix de celui de Hugo. 20 ans après, Charles Baudelaire s’emportait violemment contre ce parallèle ‘resté dans le domaine banal des idées convenues’ (Salon de 1846; Oeuvres complètes t.II, ed. Pichois, p.430-32). Jean Gandon, 'Hugo juge de Delacroix', Gazette des Beaux-arts, no.108, sept 1966, p.173-75. 'Poésies, par M. Victor Hugo', Le Globe, 4 Nov 1826, p.186

He also made a 'venomous' allusion to Les Orientales, in an article on Byron (La Quotidienne, 1 Nov [1829]).

edges.link to Goya: Hugo discovers Goya's work probably around 1828-29, perhaps through his friend Louis Boulanger
mentions of Goya: Hugo's poem 28 in 'Feuilles d'Automne' (1830) carries the epigraph 'Buen viage! - GOYA-', a reference to Capricho 64.
In 'Rayons et les ombres' (1839), Hugo compared Goya's gnomes to Rembrandt's witches and Callot's 'Temptation of Saint Anthony' (1635).
bibliography: Assante di Panzillo 2008, p.107 (Goya's mention in 'Rayons et les ombres').
Jean Adhémar & Jacques Lethève, 1958, vol. 10, p.527: they highlight 'his taste for violent contrasts of shadow and light'.
Paul Guinard 1957, p.102: Goya as Hugo's 'spiritual heir' in his use of nightmarish visions and tragic imagery, as well as sensual and picaresque themes'.

Adhémar 1935, XXVII. '[Hugo] must have observed enthusiastically the witches and demons that writhe in a darkness penetrated by violent glimmers, because his vision is very close to that of Goya. These prints must have nurtured his imagination, providing him with an endlessly rich repertoire of figures and themes from which he could draw for years' (p.XXVII).
Hugo-Hetzel 1857, p.297 (Goya's mention in 'Rayons et les ombres').

edges.discovers Goya's works: during his childhood, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (father of his close friends Louis and Félix), who brings to France Goya's portrait (1798) and a set of the Caprichos from Spain c.1800
edges.copies after Goya: at least 42 (see Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, Catalogue of Eugène Delacroix's Works after Goya's Caprichos (c.1819-1827)
edges.artworks influenced by Goya: among others, the cover of Faust (1828), based on Capricho 66
